title: 106_s1196
content: The Act titled "National Forensic Sciences Improvement Act of 1999" aims to enhance the quality, timeliness, and credibility of forensic science services for criminal justice purposes. The Drug Control and System Improvement Grant Program aims to improve the quality, timeliness, and credibility of forensic science services for criminal justice purposes. State applications for grants must include plans to enhance forensic science services. The State must have an established forensic science laboratory or system that employs full-time scientists for examining physical evidence and providing testimony in criminal matters. The State must have an established forensic science laboratory that follows accepted practices and is accredited by relevant organizations like the Laboratory Accreditation Board of the American Society of Crime Laboratory Directors or the National Association of Medical Examiners. The text chunk discusses the requirements for forensic science laboratories to receive grants, including following accepted practices and obtaining accreditation from specific organizations within two years of receiving the grant. The Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to redesignate parts and sections, including inserting a new part after part Y. The Attorney General will award grants to States for forensic sciences improvement in accordance with the Safe Streets Act of 1968. To request a grant under this part, a State must submit a certification of a consolidated State plan, ensure forensic labs meet standards, describe any new facility to be built, and certify that the grant won't fund more than 40% of the costs. The grant will not fund more than 40% of the total costs of the facility. "SEC. 2603. ALLOCATION. The grant will not fund more than 40% of the total costs of the facility." "In each fiscal year, States meeting requirements of section 2602 receive funding based on their population ratio. The term 'State' includes several regions, with American Samoa and the Northern Mariana Islands considered as one State for allocation purposes." "In each fiscal year, funding is allocated based on population ratio to States, including American Samoa and the Northern Mariana Islands. 67 percent of the amount allocated goes to American Samoa, and 33 percent goes to the Northern Mariana Islands." "SEC. 2604. USE OF GRANTS." A State receiving a grant must use it to improve forensic science or medical examiner services. The grant can only be used for specific program expenses and not for general law enforcement. Additionally, the grant cannot fund more than 40% of new facility costs and administrative costs are limited to 10% of the total. Administrative costs for grants awarded under this part are limited to 10% of the total amount. "Administrative provisions under SEC. 2605 limit costs for grants to 10% of the total amount." The Attorney General may establish regulations for grant applications and expenditure records. States receiving grants must maintain records for audits, with access granted to the Attorney General and Comptroller General for examination. The Attorney General can establish regulations for grant applications and expenditure records. The book, document, or record must be related to the grant receipt or use for examination by the Attorney General, Comptroller General, or their designee. SEC. 2606. REPORTS. Each State receiving a grant under this part must submit a report to the Attorney General each fiscal year, summarizing the program carried out with the grant and providing other required information. The Attorney General must also submit a report to Congress within 90 days after the fiscal year, detailing the total amount of grants awarded and summarizing the information provided by the States. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2000 to 2004 under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968.
